--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Stephen Waits <steve@...> wrote:

> Mike,
> 
>=
 It's a good question.
> 
> Whenever you go to add an innovation to your gl=
obal innovation list,
you 
> need to first search to determine if that inno=
vation already exists.
 If 
> it does exist, then you should simply reuse t=
hat innovation ID.  If it 
> doesn't exist, then you create a new innovatio=
n ID.
> 
> How you store innovations so that you can do these searches quic=
kly is 
> up to you.  It may vary depending on your implementation language=
, 
> programming paradigm, or personal preference.  Commonly, you might
use=
 a 
> hash table (std::map<> in C++) or maintain an ordered list of 
> inno=
vations (thereby making a binary search possible).
> 
> Personally, in C++,=
 I keep two innovation lists.  One is my global
list, 
> the other is the l=
ist of new innovations for the current generation.
 It 
> works something l=
ike this.
> 
> GetInnovationId
>    Binary search global Innovation list - =
if found return id
>    Linear search generation Innovation list - if found=
 return id
>    Add new id to generation Innovation list
> 
> At end of eac=
h Generation
>    Copy generation Innovation list to global Innovation list=

>    Clear generation Innovation list
>    Sort global Innovation list
> 
=
> In words..  Any new innovations, within a single generation, are 
> maint=
ained in an unsorted list.  At the end of each generation, that 
> unsorted=
 list is merged into the master sorted list.  The advantage of 
> this sche=
me is that searching for Innovations remains very fast and 
> storage remai=
ns O(n).  One disadvantage is that it's slightly more
complex.
> 
> Hope th=
at helps.
> 
> --Steve
>

Steve,

Thanks for the quick response.

The idea =
of the two innovation lists is interesting and one I hadn't
thought of.

>I=
f it does exist, then you should simply reuse that innovation ID
This is th=
e bit I'm still not clear on. In my example, things work OK
up to & includi=
ng adding innovation number 6 (link 3 to 5). 
But for the second genome whe=
n we try to add innovation number 7 (5 to
4) should we simply resuse innova=
tion number 5 (5 to 4)?
(even though when we draw out the resulting phenoty=
pes the 5 to 4
links are in two different places on the network).

Mike
